column5: SPARK.  Equality budgeting is an approach to economic policy making and planning that places equality at the centre of decisions concerning public expenditure and income.  Through equality audits and impact assessments
column6: equality budgeting provides information on how different sections of society are impacted by specific economic policy  measures.  The objective of equality budgeting lies in ensuring this information is made available to public representatives in order that they can make informed policy decisions that achieve the best outcomes for specific disadvantaged groups but also for society at large.  Equality budgeting goes beyond traditional approaches to policy making and planning by
column8: assessing the impact of expenditure resources on different sections of society
column9: assessing who does and does not benefit
column10: integrating equality as a driving principle and perhaps
column12: increasing transparency in the budgetary process.Equality budgeting provides the following benefits: increased levels of information
column13: including disaggregated data and impact assessment; increased levels of equality
column14: including knowledge of who is disproportionately impacted
column16: implementation and review; increased levels of transparency through the publication of information to show members of the public how they are affected; and reform to budgetary process
column17: such as draft budget and meaningful engagement of stakeholder and legislators. I will briefly outline how equality budgeting operates in other jurisdictions
column18: as per the request of the committee. Equality budgeting originated in the 1980s in the form of gender budgeting and was pioneered by Australia. More than 60 countries have implemented or worked towards equality budgeting since then
column22: Tanzania and Uganda. Some work was done in Ireland toward this

column27: made up of government and civil society actors

column29: which highlights equality outcomes by theme

column38: money was allocated to projects aimed at tackling the higher costs faced by parents bringing up disabled children; targeting fathers in parenting programmes; and providing translated resources so that programmes are more inclusive of parents and children from ethnic minorities.
